Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2007 07:40PM - edited Nov 21, 2007 07:46PM by karenann Kimmy, When I was on Herceptin I had a lot of eye (ocular migraines), sinus and ear problems.  Shortly after flying one time I got a horrible case of vertigo.  Let's see if I can remember what they called it... benign positional vertigo.  Apparently, some of the hairs in the ear canal had broken off and were floating around causing vertigo.  The emergency room doc had me do all kinds of "weird" things with my head to get the hairs to move out of the canal.  It did work and I felt a lot better, however, I did experience a bit of dizziness and nausea for a couple of days. Did you experience pressure change on your trip?  An increase or decrease in altitude?  If so, maybe you are experiencing what I had. I hope you feel better soon. Karen

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2008 07:47PM karenann wrote: I am sure that you can have grade 1 and er/pr- breast cancer and you are right when defining what grade means.  If I remember correctly, your mom went from DCIS to stage 4... is that right?  Did anyone ever discuss the possibility that your mom had some invasive cancer that was not detected at the time of dx?  If so, and she was er/pr- then there would be no treatment (maybe rads) and the cancer just grew until it was stage 4. The question about Her2... the best place to get that question answered is the Her2 Support Group board.  I know that most DCIS is Her2+++ but 1mm of invasive cancer, I am not sure about that.  I was under the impression that the Her2 status is always tested, however, I don't know if size is an issue. Karen

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 01:41PM - edited Jan 29, 2008 01:42PM by karenann Hi, There are many stories similar to yours and woman are living very long and productive lives with mets.  One of the blessings you have with your mets dx is that you are er+/pr+ and Her2+++.   You have hormonals you can use and Herceptin. There is a site for Her2+ bc, the website is www.Her2support.org.  Christine and Joe started the site after Christine's cancer metastisized to her brain and lungs, I think about 9 years ago.  There are many women on that site living with cancer and have been for a long time. It also helps to see what other women who are Her2+ with mets are receiving for treatment. Hope this helps. Karen

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2008 04:07AM - edited Mar 27, 2008 05:02AM by karenann One thing I have learned about this disease is anything is possible.  When I was first dx with bc one of the nurses that came to my support group said that typically, Her2+ bc is er/pr- and usually not er/pr+.  Guess what?  I and several other women in the support group were er/pr+ and Her2+.  Also, usually when your are Her2+ the grade is 3.  Again, all 4 of us that were Her2+ had different grades of cancer as do many of the women on the Her2 support group board.  So, I guess what I am saying, is that maybe some of the articles you read say one thing but women can have er/pr- bc and be grade 1. Hugs,  Karen
